Internal state control
Flags controlling the configuration state of individual variables and the configuration itself

The variables are publicly accessible but of limited use for clients. Typically, a value of false indicates a default setting for the corresponding data.

Detailed Description

Configuration data container.

Singleton instance shares configuration data across all modules.This container maintains a keyed store of configuration keys and the associated data (usually given in the command line and/or an input file). The interpreter can only recognize fairly simple syntax of the form 

 {.cpp} 
 --<key>=<value>
 --<key>

No spaces are allowed between the -- sign and the keyword <key>, and around the assignment symbol (if any). Also, any quotes or double quotes around the value are likely removed. The option without value indicates a boolean switch, with the interpretation that the associated data word is true of the switch is set. Full control on boolean switches can also be achieved by 

 {.cpp}
 --<key>=true
 --<key>=false
Note that in this case the test on the true or strings is case insensitive, meaning --<key>=True yields the same result as --<key>=true.

Keywords need to be sufficiently different. E.g., 

 {.cpp}
 --outputFile=test.root
 --outoutFileOpts=recreate
will not work, as the system will overwrite the outputFile when encountering outputFileOpts. This should probably be fixed soon.

The data is internally stored as std::string, there is no particular attempt made to guess the data value type. On the fly conversion in the query to retrieve the data associated with a key is available for simple data types like int, `long int`, `long long int`, float, double, and bool. In addition to these POD types the stored value can always be accessed in its internal representation std::string.

In addition, client defined configuration data can be stored. The data has to be provided with same syntax as discussed above, with a client chosen keyword and, if appropriate, value.

const std::string &  cmt = "client configuraton"

Add configuration data with a given key.

Parameters:
[in] key key for data
[in] data string representing data word
[in] cmt optional comment for configuration
Returns:
true if everything went well (no real error mode anyway).
Note:
If data already exists for a given key, it is overwritten.

template<class C>
bool Configuration::ConfigData::getConfig ( const std::string &  key,
C &  data 
)

General data look-up.

Parameters:
[in] key key for data
[in] data reference to modifiable data word containing data found in look-up table on return
Returns:
true if key exists in map. If key does not exist in map, false is returned and the content of data is unchanged.

Empty string tag

std::string Configuration::ConfigData::mainName

Application name.

Constructed automatically from argv[0] for command line. Can be set in steering file using the keyword "mainName" (not yet implemented).

int Configuration::ConfigData::nEvents

Number of requested signal events.

Total number of interactions per event is nEvents * mu .

Note:
This the number of requested events. The number of analyzed events is controlled by the number of events avaliable for signal events and pile-up events in the inout stream(s) such that the total number of analyzed events is equal to, or lower than, nEvents .

std::string Configuration::ConfigData::outputFile

Output file name.

This can be the complete name in case of useMu=true . Else, this variable is used as a template for form the output file name, e.g., 

   ConfigData::mu = 20;
   ConfigData::outputFile = "test.root";
on input creates file name outputFile="test20.root" .

bool Configuration::ConfigData::useMu

Flags use of automatic output file name creation.

useMu=true generates outout file name explicitely containing the mu value.
